case_name: State of Uttar Pradesh v. Singhara Singh, Bir Singh and Tega Singh

facts.text: Raja Ram, a shopkeeper of Afzalgarh in Uttar Pradesh, was murdered by gunshot in his shop

anchor.surface_text: On March 20, 1959, Raja Ram, a shopkeeper, of Afzalgarh in the State of Uttar Pradesh was murdered by gunshot in his shop.

facts.text: Seven persons including Singhara Singh, Bir Singh and Tega Singh were prosecuted for the murder of Raja Ram

anchor.surface_text: Seven persons including the three respondents, Singhara Singh, Bir Singh and Tega Singh were prosecuted for this murder.

facts.text: Additional Sessions Judge of Bijnor convicted Singhara Singh of murder under S. 302 IPC and sentenced him to death

anchor.surface_text: The learned Additional Sessions judge of Bijnor before whom the trial was held, convicted the respondent Singhara Singh of the murder under S. 302 of the Indian Penal Code and sentenced him to death.

facts.text: Additional Sessions Judge convicted Bir Singh and Tega Singh of abetment of murder under S. 302 read with ss. 120B, 109 and 114 IPC, sentenced Bir Singh to death and Tega Singh to life imprisonment

anchor.surface_text: He convicted the respondents Bir Singh and Tega Singh of abetment of the murder under S. 302 read with ss. 120B, 109 and 114 of the said Code and sentenced Bir Singh to death and Tega Singh to imprisonment for life.

facts.text: Additional Sessions Judge acquitted the other accused persons

anchor.surface_text: He acquitted the other accused persons.

facts.text: Respondents appealed convictions to Allahabad High Court, State appealed acquittals

anchor.surface_text: The respondents appealed from the conviction to the High Court at Allahabad and the State from the acquittal.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court had Reference No. 142 of 1960 for confirmation of death sentences

anchor.surface_text: The High Court had also before it the usual reference for Confirmation of the sentences of death.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court allowed appeals of respondents, dismissed State's appeal, rejected reference on May 31, 1961 in Criminal Appeals Nos. 2017 and 2109 of 1960

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 31 of 1962. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated May, 31, 1961, of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Appeals Nos. 2017 and 2109 of 1960 and Reference No. 142 of 1960.

facts.text: State filed appeal to Supreme Court by special leave as Criminal Appeal No. 31 of 1962

anchor.surface_text: B. Agarwala, G. C. Mathur and C. P. Lal, for the appellant. Nuruddin Ahmed and V. D. Misra, for the respondents. August 16, 1963. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SARKAR J.--

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave only concerning the three respondents

anchor.surface_text: The State has now filed this appeal against the judgment of the High Court by special leave. This Court however granted the leave only so far as the judgment of the High Court concerned the three respondents.

facts.text: Only point argued in Supreme Court appeal was admissibility of certain oral evidence

anchor.surface_text: The only point argued in this appeal was as to the admissibility of certain oral evidence.

facts.text: Conceded that if oral evidence inadmissible, no other evidence to convict respondents

anchor.surface_text: It is conceded that if that evidence was not admissible, then there is no other evidence on which the respondents can be convicted.

facts.text: Mr. Dixit, a second class magistrate, recorded confessions of guilt by respondents under s.164 CrPC

anchor.surface_text: Now, the evidence with which this case is concerned was given by a learned magistrate, Mr. Dixit, of confessions of guilt made to him by the respondents and purported to have been recorded by him under s. 164

facts.text: Prosecution unable to prove Mr. Dixit specially empowered by State Government under s.164 CrPC

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Dixit, who recorded the confession in this case was a second class magistrate and the prosecution was unable to prove that he had been specially empowered by the State Government to record a statement or confession under s. 164 of the Code.

facts.text: Confessions not recorded under s.164, record not admissible under ss.74 and 80 Evidence Act

anchor.surface_text: The trial, therefore, proceeded on the basis that he had not been so empowered. That being so, it was rightly held that the confessions had not been recorded under s. 164 and the record could not be put in evidence under ss. 74 and 80 of the Evidence Act to prove them.

facts.text: Prosecution called Mr. Dixit to prove confessions orally, refreshing memory from record under s.159 Evidence Act

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution, thereupon called Mr. Dixit to prove these confessions, the record being used only to refresh his memory under s. 159 of the Evidence Act. It is the admissibility of this oral evidence that is in question.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered by Sarkar J. on August 16, 1963

anchor.surface_text: Nuruddin Ahmed and V. D. Misra, for the respondents. August 16, 1963. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SARKAR J.--

facts.text: Trial held before Additional Sessions Judge of Bijnor

anchor.surface_text: The learned Additional Sessions judge of Bijnor before whom the trial was held,

facts.text: Allahabad High Court acquitted the respondents

anchor.surface_text: In other words, it is not in dispute that if that evidence was not admissible the High Courts decision acquitting the respondents cannot be questioned.

facts.text: Supreme Court held oral evidence of Mr. Dixit inadmissible

anchor.surface_text: We think that the High Court in the present case rightly rejected the oral evidence of Mr. Dixit.

under s. 164 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. The terms of that section and certain other sections of the Code on the interpretation of which this case depends, are as follows S. 164

concepts.interpretation: Only Presidency Magistrates, first class Magistrates, or second class Magistrates specially empowered by State Government can record confessions; if purportedly recorded by non-empowered magistrate, oral evidence of confession inadmissible to bypass safeguards.

anchor.surface_text: Nothing in this section shall be deemed to apply to, the examination of an accused person under section 263 or in the course of a trial held by a Presidency Magistrate

issues.text: Whether the oral evidence given by Mr. Dixit of the confessions purportedly recorded by him under s. 164 CrPC is admissible

anchor.surface_text: It is the admissibility of this oral evidence that is in question. The Judicial Committee in Nazir Ahmed v. The King Emperor held that when a magistrate of the first class records a confession under s. 164 but does not follow the procedure laid down in that section, oral evidence of the confession is inadmissible.

issues.text: Whether Nazir Ahmed's case applies where the magistrate recording the confession under s. 164 is not specially empowered as a second class magistrate

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Aggarwala then contended that Nazir Ahmed’s case was distinguishable. He said that all that the Judicial Committee decided in Nazir Ahmed’s case was that if a Presidency Magistrate, a Magistrate of the first class or a Magistrate of the second class specially empowered in that behalf records a statement or confession under s. 164 but the procedure laid down in it is not complied with, he cannot give oral evidence

issues.text: Whether s. 533 CrPC permits oral evidence to prove a confession purportedly recorded under s. 164 by a non-empowered magistrate or shows that s. 164 procedure is not mandatory

anchor.surface_text: What he meant was that s. 533 of the Code showed that in recording a statement or confession under s. 164, it was not obligatory for the magistrate to follow the procedure mentioned in it. Section 533 says that if the court before which a statement or confession of an accused person purporting to be recorded under s. 164 or s. 364 is tendered

issues.text: Whether the principle in Taylor v. Taylor applies to s. 164 CrPC prohibiting other methods of proof like oral evidence

anchor.surface_text: In Nazir Ahmed’s case the Judicial Committee observed that the principle applied in Taylor v. Taylor to a Court, namely, that where a power is given to do a certain thing in a certain way, the thing must be done in that way or not at all and that other methods of performance are necessarily forbidden, applied to judicial officers making a record under s. 164

arguments.claim: Oral evidence of confession inadmissible if s.164 procedure not followed (Nazir Ahmed; Taylor principle applies to judicial officers under s.164)

anchor.surface_text: The Judicial Committee in Nazir Ahmed v. The King Emperor 1  held that when a magistrate of the first class records a confession under s. 164 but does not follow the procedure laid down in that section, oral evidence of the confession is inadmissible... the principle applied in Taylor v. Taylor 3  to a Court... applied to judicial officers making a record under s. 164

arguments.claim: s.533 does not make s.164 procedure optional but requires proof of compliance if record defective

anchor.surface_text: What s. 533 therefore does is to permit oral evidence to be given to prove that the procedure laid down in s. 164 had,in fact-been followed when the court finds that the record produced before it does not show that was so.

arguments.claim: Power under s.164 only for specified magistrates; non-empowered cannot record validly, oral evidence prohibited to uphold safeguards

anchor.surface_text: When a statute confers a power on certain judicial officers, that power can obviously be exercised only by those officers... it would be an unnatural construction of the section to hold that these safeguards were not thought necessary... where the confession had been made to a magistrate of a lower class

arguments.claim: Nazir Ahmed affirmed by Supreme Court in Rao Shiv Bahadur Singh and Deep Chand

anchor.surface_text: We have to point out that the correctness of the decision of Nazir Ahmeds case 1  has been accepted by this Court in at least two cases, namely, Rao Shiv Bahadur Singh v. The State of Vindhya Pradesh 2  and Deep Chand v. State of Rajasthan 3 .

holdings.text: The oral evidence given by Mr. Dixit of the confessions purportedly recorded by him under s. 164 CrPC is inadmissible

anchor.surface_text: We think that the High Court in the present case rightly rejected the oral evidence of Mr. Dixit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies Nazir Ahmed principle via Taylor v Taylor exclusive method doctrine; s.164 safeguards for accused cannot be bypassed by oral testimony even from non-empowered magistrate; affirms prior SC precedents

holdings.text: Nazir Ahmed's case applies where a second class magistrate not specially empowered under s.164 purports to record a confession; such magistrate cannot give oral evidence of the confession

anchor.surface_text: The principle applied in that decision would however equally prevent such a magistrate from giving oral evidence of the confession. When a statute confers a power on certain judicial officers...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Power under s.164 conferred only on specified classes of magistrates; principle prevents bypassing safeguards equally or more strongly for lower class magistrates; unnatural to allow lower magistrates to ignore safeguards

holdings.text: S.533 CrPC does not permit oral evidence to prove confessions purportedly recorded under s.164 by non-empowered magistrate; it only allows proof of compliance with procedure where record is facially defective

anchor.surface_text: What s. 533 therefore does is to permit oral evidence to be given to prove that the procedure laid down in s. 164 had,in fact-been followed when the court finds that the record produced before it does not show that was so.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation harmonized with s.164; s.533 requires proof that procedure was followed for admission, emphasizing mandatory nature rather than optionality

holdings.text: The principle in Taylor v. Taylor (exclusive method doctrine) applies to judicial officers recording under s.164 CrPC, prohibiting alternative methods of proof like oral evidence

anchor.surface_text: In Nazir Ahmed’s case the Judicial Committee observed that the principle applied in Taylor v. Taylor 3  to a Court, namely, that where a power is given to do a certain thing in a certain way...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms Judicial Committee adoption of Taylor principle to s.164; statutory power to record implies prohibition on other proof methods to preserve safeguards

holdings.text: Nazir Ahmed's case was correctly decided and has been accepted by this Court in Rao Shiv Bahadur Singh and Deep Chand

anchor.surface_text: We have to point out that the correctness of the decision of Nazir Ahmeds case 1  has been accepted by this Court in at least two cases, namely, Rao Shiv Bahadur Singh v. The State of Vindhya Pradesh 2  and Deep Chand v. State of Rajasthan 3 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior SC affirmations confirm validity against challenges to Nazir on s.533 and object of s.164

holdings.text: Confessions purportedly recorded by second class magistrate not specially empowered were not recorded under s.164 and inadmissible under ss.74 and 80 Evidence Act

anchor.surface_text: The trial, therefore, proceeded on the basis that he had not been so empowered. That being so, it was rightly held that the confessions had not been recorded under s. 164 and the record could not be put in evidence under ss. 74 and 80 of the Evidence Act to prove them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prosecution failed to prove empowerment; only duly recorded s.164 confessions qualify as public documents

holdings.text: Ashrafi v. State does not apply to confessions under s.164; doubts on its view that non-specified magistrates can prove statements orally

anchor.surface_text: We are not very clear as to what exactly was intended to be laid down in this case about s. 164. Furthermore it does not appear to us from the report how the observations...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ashrafi concerned identification parades by first class magistrate; observations obiter and unnecessary; later case doubts it; inapplicable to confessions

holdings.text: Ghulam Hussain v. King concerns relevancy of non-confession statements under Evidence Act ss.18-21, not proof via oral evidence under s.164

anchor.surface_text: That case only held that the relevancy of a statement recorded under s. 164 had to be decided by the provisions, of the Evidence Act. We have nothing to do with any question as to relevancy of evidence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes relevancy (admissions) from mode of proof prohibited by s.164

holdings.text: Emperor v. Ram Naresh does not assist; petition not purporting to be s.164 record, admissible under s.21 Evidence Act as admission

anchor.surface_text: It was held, and we think rightly, that Nazir Ahmeds case 5  did not prevent the petition being admitted in evidence because it only forbade certain oral evidence being given.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Wholly different facts; not under s.164; Nazir forbids specific oral evidence of purported s.164 confessions

holdings.text: Does not decide whether/how far identification memorandum is under s.164 or support Ashrafi view on non-specified magistrates

anchor.surface_text: It is not necessary for us in this judgment to decide whether or how far a memorandum of identification proceeding is a statement recorded under s. 164 and we do not wish to be understood as lending our support...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unnecessary to decision; reserves opinion on identification parades

outcome.relief_summary: State's appeal dismissed; High Court's acquittal of respondents Singhara Singh, Bir Singh and Tega Singh upheld due to inadmissibility of oral evidence of confessions

edges.explanation: a2 argues Ashrafi not applicable as it dealt with identification parades, attacking a7's reliance on Ashrafi for oral evidence
Argument that oral evidence inadmissible and High Court rightly rejected it supports the holding
Argument on Nazir Ahmed governing and oral evidence inadmissible addresses the admissibility issue
Concession that if oral evidence inadmissible no other evidence to convict addresses the importance of the admissibility issue
a4 argues Nazir wrongly decided, attacking a2's position that case governed by Nazir
Argument that Nazir wrongly decided and s.533 permits oral evidence rebuts the holding of inadmissibility
Argument challenging Nazir and supporting oral evidence via s.533 addresses the admissibility issue
Argument that Ashrafi supports oral evidence rebuts the holding of inadmissibility
Argument on Ashrafi supporting oral evidence where magistrate not specified addresses the admissibility issue
S.159 concept that oral testimony inadmissible supports a2's argument for inadmissibility
S.159 concept holding oral testimony inadmissible rebuts a4's argument for oral evidence admissibility
S.159 concept holding oral testimony inadmissible rebuts a7's argument based on Ashrafi for oral evidence
